segment.source: BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions
segment.target: BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions

segment.source: BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions
segment.target: BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions

segment.source: BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions
segment.target: BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions

segment.source: Create custom partition layouts for your hard disk drives (HDDs), solid-state drives (SSDs), and other drives when deploying Windows to BIOS–based devices.
segment.target: Create custom partition layouts for your hard disk drives (HDDs), solid-state drives (SSDs), and other drives when deploying Windows to BIOS–based devices.

segment.source: Note If you use a custom partition layout on Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education), update the push-button recovery script so the recovery tools can recreate the custom partition layout when needed.
segment.target: Note If you use a custom partition layout on Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education), update the push-button recovery script so the recovery tools can recreate the custom partition layout when needed.

segment.source: Drive partition rules
segment.target: Drive partition rules

segment.source: When you deploy Windows to a BIOS-based device, you must format hard drives by using an MBR file system.
segment.target: When you deploy Windows to a BIOS-based device, you must format hard drives by using an MBR file system.

segment.source: Windows does not support the GUID partition table (GPT) file system on BIOS-based computers.
segment.target: Windows does not support the GUID partition table (GPT) file system on BIOS-based computers.

segment.source: An MBR drive can have up to four standard partitions.
segment.target: An MBR drive can have up to four standard partitions.

segment.source: Typically, these standard partitions are designated as primary partitions.
segment.target: Typically, these standard partitions are designated as primary partitions.

segment.source: For information about how to create additional partitions beyond this limit, see Configure More than Four Partitions on a BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Disk.
segment.target: For information about how to create additional partitions beyond this limit, see Configure More than Four Partitions on a BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Disk.

segment.source: Windows partition requirements:
segment.target: Windows partition requirements:

segment.source: System partition
segment.target: System partition

segment.source: Each bootable drive must contain a system partition.
segment.target: Each bootable drive must contain a system partition.

segment.source: The system partition must be configured as the active partition.
segment.target: The system partition must be configured as the active partition.

segment.source: The minimum size of this partition is 100 MB.
segment.target: The minimum size of this partition is 100 MB.

segment.source: Windows partition
segment.target: Windows partition

segment.source: This partition must have at least 20 gigabytes (GB) of drive space for 64-bit versions, or 16 GB for 32-bit versions.
segment.target: This partition must have at least 20 gigabytes (GB) of drive space for 64-bit versions, or 16 GB for 32-bit versions.

segment.source: This partition must be formatted using the NTFS file format.
segment.target: This partition must be formatted using the NTFS file format.

segment.source: This partition must have enough 10 GB of free space after the user has completed the Out Of Box Experience (OOBE).
segment.target: This partition must have enough 10 GB of free space after the user has completed the Out Of Box Experience (OOBE).

segment.source: This partition can have a maximum of 2 terabytes (TB) of space.
segment.target: This partition can have a maximum of 2 terabytes (TB) of space.

segment.source: Software tools to extend the visible partition space beyond 2 TB are not supported on BIOS because they can interfere with software solutions for application compatibility and recovery.
segment.target: Software tools to extend the visible partition space beyond 2 TB are not supported on BIOS because they can interfere with software solutions for application compatibility and recovery.

segment.source: Recovery tools partition
segment.target: Recovery tools partition

segment.source: The Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE) tools image (winre.wim) should be in a separate partition than the Windows partition to support automatic failover and to support booting Windows BitLocker Drive Encryption-encrypted partitions.
segment.target: The Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE) tools image (winre.wim) should be in a separate partition than the Windows partition to support automatic failover and to support booting Windows BitLocker Drive Encryption-encrypted partitions.

segment.source: While this image can be included on the same partition as the system partition, we recommend that you place this partition in a separate partition, immediately after the Windows partition.
segment.target: While this image can be included on the same partition as the system partition, we recommend that you place this partition in a separate partition, immediately after the Windows partition.

segment.source: This allows Windows to modify and recreate the partition later if future updates require a larger recovery image.
segment.target: This allows Windows to modify and recreate the partition later if future updates require a larger recovery image.

segment.source: This partition must have enough space for the Windows Recovery Environment tools image (winre.wim, typically between 250-300MB, depending on base language and customizations added), plus enough free space so that the partition can be captured by backup utilities:
segment.target: This partition must have enough space for the Windows Recovery Environment tools image (winre.wim, typically between 250-300MB, depending on base language and customizations added), plus enough free space so that the partition can be captured by backup utilities:

segment.source: If the partition is less than 500 MB, it must have at least 50 MB of free space.
segment.target: If the partition is less than 500 MB, it must have at least 50 MB of free space.

segment.source: If the partition is 500 MB or larger, it must have at least 320 MB of free space.
segment.target: If the partition is 500 MB or larger, it must have at least 320 MB of free space.

segment.source: If the partition is larger than 1 GB, we recommend that it should have at least 1 GB free.
segment.target: If the partition is larger than 1 GB, we recommend that it should have at least 1 GB free.

segment.source: It must have at least 320 MB of free space.
segment.target: It must have at least 320 MB of free space.

segment.source: We recommend that it should have at least 1 GB free.
segment.target: We recommend that it should have at least 1 GB free.

segment.source: Data partitions
segment.target: Data partitions

segment.source: The recommended partition layout for Windows 10 does not include utility or data partitions.
segment.target: The recommended partition layout for Windows 10 does not include utility or data partitions.

segment.source: However, if utility or data partitions are required, they should be placed either before the Windows partition or after the Windows RE partition.
segment.target: However, if utility or data partitions are required, they should be placed either before the Windows partition or after the Windows RE partition.

segment.source: By keeping the Windows and recovery partitions together, then when future updates of Windows RE area available, Windows will be able to grow the Windows RE partition by shrinking the Windows partition.
segment.target: By keeping the Windows and recovery partitions together, then when future updates of Windows RE area available, Windows will be able to grow the Windows RE partition by shrinking the Windows partition.

segment.source: This layout makes it more difficult for end users to remove the data partition and merge the space with the Windows partition.
segment.target: This layout makes it more difficult for end users to remove the data partition and merge the space with the Windows partition.

segment.source: For example, the Windows RE partition may need to be moved to the end of the unused space reclaimed from the data partition, so that the Windows partition can be extended.
segment.target: For example, the Windows RE partition may need to be moved to the end of the unused space reclaimed from the data partition, so that the Windows partition can be extended.

segment.source: Windows 10 does not include functionality or utility to facilitate this process.
segment.target: Windows 10 does not include functionality or utility to facilitate this process.

segment.source: However, manufacturers can develop and provide such a utility if PCs are shipped with data partitions.
segment.target: However, manufacturers can develop and provide such a utility if PCs are shipped with data partitions.

segment.source: Each partition can have a maximum of 2 terabytes (TB) of space.
segment.target: Each partition can have a maximum of 2 terabytes (TB) of space.

segment.source: If you're going to be adding more than four total partitions to the disk, see Configure More than Four Partitions on a BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Disk for more info.
segment.target: If you're going to be adding more than four total partitions to the disk, see Configure More than Four Partitions on a BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Disk for more info.

segment.source: Partition layout
segment.target: Partition layout

segment.source: If you install Windows using a bootable USB key made by Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD), it creates the following layout by default: a system partition, a Windows partition, and a recovery tools partition.
segment.target: If you install Windows using a bootable USB key made by Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD), it creates the following layout by default: a system partition, a Windows partition, and a recovery tools partition.

segment.source: diagram of default partition layout: system, windows, and recovery
segment.target: diagram of default partition layout: system, windows, and recovery

segment.source: System and utility partitions
segment.target: System and utility partitions

segment.source: By default, system partitions do not appear in File Explorer.
segment.target: By default, system partitions do not appear in File Explorer.

segment.source: This helps protect end users from accidentally modifying a partition.
segment.target: This helps protect end users from accidentally modifying a partition.

segment.source: To set partitions as utility partitions
segment.target: To set partitions as utility partitions

segment.source: When you are deploying Windows by using Windows ICD, the partition type will be set automatically.
segment.target: When you are deploying Windows by using Windows ICD, the partition type will be set automatically.

segment.source: When you are deploying Windows by using the DiskPart tool, use the set id=27 command after you create the partition.
segment.target: When you are deploying Windows by using the DiskPart tool, use the set id=27 command after you create the partition.

segment.source: To verify that system and utility partitions exist
segment.target: To verify that system and utility partitions exist

segment.source: Click Start, right-click This PC, and then click Manage.
segment.target: Click Start, right-click This PC, and then click Manage.

segment.source: The Computer Management window opens.
segment.target: The Computer Management window opens.

segment.source: Click Disk Management.
segment.target: Click Disk Management.

segment.source: The list of available drives and partitions appears.
segment.target: The list of available drives and partitions appears.

segment.source: In the list of drives and partitions, confirm that the system and utility partitions are present and are not assigned a drive letter.
segment.target: In the list of drives and partitions, confirm that the system and utility partitions are present and are not assigned a drive letter.

segment.source: Sample files: configuring disk layout by using Windows PE and DiskPart scripts
segment.target: Sample files: configuring disk layout by using Windows PE and DiskPart scripts

segment.source: For image-based deployment, boot the PC to Windows PE, and then use the DiskPart tool to create the partition structures on your destination PCs.
segment.target: For image-based deployment, boot the PC to Windows PE, and then use the DiskPart tool to create the partition structures on your destination PCs.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: In these DiskPart examples, the partitions are assigned the letters: System=S, Windows=W, and Recovery=R.
segment.target: In these DiskPart examples, the partitions are assigned the letters: System=S, Windows=W, and Recovery=R.

segment.source: We recommend changing the Windows drive letter to a letter that’s near the end of the alphabet, such as W, to avoid drive letter conflicts.
segment.target: We recommend changing the Windows drive letter to a letter that’s near the end of the alphabet, such as W, to avoid drive letter conflicts.

segment.source: Do not use X, because this drive letter is reserved for Windows PE.
segment.target: Do not use X, because this drive letter is reserved for Windows PE.

segment.source: After the device reboots, the Windows partition is assigned the letter C, and the other partitions don’t receive drive letters.
segment.target: After the device reboots, the Windows partition is assigned the letter C, and the other partitions don’t receive drive letters.

segment.source: If you reboot, Windows PE reassigns disk letters alphabetically, starting with the letter C, without regard to the configuration in Windows Setup.
segment.target: If you reboot, Windows PE reassigns disk letters alphabetically, starting with the letter C, without regard to the configuration in Windows Setup.

segment.source: This configuration can change based on the presence of different drives, such as USB flash drives.
segment.target: This configuration can change based on the presence of different drives, such as USB flash drives.

segment.source: The following steps describe how to partition your hard drives and prepare to apply images.
segment.target: The following steps describe how to partition your hard drives and prepare to apply images.

segment.source: You can use the code in the sections that follow to complete these steps.
segment.target: You can use the code in the sections that follow to complete these steps.

segment.source: To partition hard drives and prepare to apply images
segment.target: To partition hard drives and prepare to apply images

segment.source: Save the following code as a text file (CreatePartitions-BIOS.txt) on a USB flash drive.
segment.target: Save the following code as a text file (CreatePartitions-BIOS.txt) on a USB flash drive.

segment.source: Use Windows PE to boot the destination computer.
segment.target: Use Windows PE to boot the destination computer.

segment.source: Clean and partition the drive.
segment.target: Clean and partition the drive.

segment.source: In this example, F is the letter of the USB flash drive.
segment.target: In this example, F is the letter of the USB flash drive.

segment.source: If you use a custom partition layout on Windows 10 for desktop editions, update the push-button recovery script so the recovery tools can recreate the custom partition layout when needed.
segment.target: If you use a custom partition layout on Windows 10 for desktop editions, update the push-button recovery script so the recovery tools can recreate the custom partition layout when needed.

segment.source: Next steps
segment.target: Next steps

segment.source: Use a deployment script to apply the Windows images on the newly created partitions.
segment.target: Use a deployment script to apply the Windows images on the newly created partitions.

segment.source: For more information, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.
segment.target: For more information, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.
